titleStmt.title: Twitter thread on media's sympathy towards White perpetrators and criminalization of Black victims
titleStmt.author: Kaanita Iyer

persName.note: Tamir Rice was a 12-year-old boy who was shot and killed on November 22, 2014 by a Cleveland police officer who thought his toy gun was real.
Nikolas Cruz is the suspected perpetrator of the shool shooting of Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School, which killed 17 people.

Trayvon Martin was a 17-year-old boy who was shot on February 26, 2012 in Sanford, Florida, by George Zimmerman because he deemed Martin as suspicious. He was acquitted after the shooting was deemed to be self-defense.

Jordan Davis was a 17-year-old boy who was shot in Jacksonville, Florida, when he was shot by Michael Dunn after an argument between them about Davis playing loud music. Michalel Dunn was found guilty of first-degree murder.
Aiyana Stanley-Jones was shot in the head on May 16, 2010 during a police raid of her home. All charges were dropped against the suspect, Officer Joseph Weekley.

18-year-old Michael Brown of Ferguson, Missouri, was a supect in a robbery of a convenience store and was fatally shot during an encounter with the police at the scene. Suspect Darren Wilson, a police officer, claimed he shot Brown because Brown tried to take control of his gun and charged at him. Wilson was not indited.

Philando Castile was fatally shot in front of his girlfriend and her four-year-old daughter when he was pulled over in Falcon Heights, Minnesota, by Officer Jeronimo Yanez. Castile was shot while reaching for his ID because Yanez though he was pulling out his gun, which Castile informed that he had. Yanez was acquitted of all charges.

Korryn Gaines was shot in Randallstown, Maryland, during a standoff between her and the police who came to her apartment to serve a warrant. Police say Gaines threatened the officers with a shotgun and, as a result, was shot. Gaines' five-year-old son was also injured but he survived. The officer who shot Gaines did not receive any charges.
Michael Dunn was convicted of the first-degree murder of Jordan Davis. He shot Davis after an argument about Davis playing loud music.

div.p: One of these young boys is Tamir Rice(right). He was 12 years old when killed by a cop.
The other is Nikolas Cruz, who went into #Parkland &and killed 17 people. One was described as a thug; the other was called a "broken child."
Amazing when the media decides to offer humanity.

div.p: I treat young people committing offenses very seriously - and I don't believe in the death penalty, but it is heartbreaking to always see how the media treats and resonds to young blackBlack people even as victims.

In the eyes of mainstream media, there is no such thing as a blackBlack victim. Not Trayvon Martin, not Jordan Davis, not Aiyana Stanley-Jones, not even Tamir Rice. To many blacknessBlackness means perpetrator.

While I recognize many may not appreciate this comparison, I find it to be an important one. Why? Because we have to call out the anti-blackBlack racism pervasive in mainstream media and its reporting.

And for those wondering, "isIs this really about racism and anti-blacknessBlackness when Nikolas' last name is "Cruz."" Yes. And that question also means that you fail to realize that whitenessWhiteness doesn't operate within a vacuum.

Let's remember how the media treats young blackBlack people: Mike Brown was a teenager referred to as a "man" to make him older than his age indicated. He was shot as he was leaving. That didn't stop media from referring to him as a thug who deserved to die.

Philando Castile may not have been as young as Tamir Rice or Mike Brown, but had a licenced weapon and was still gunned down in front of his girlfriend and daughter. This was filmed live. The terroristic NRA basically said "we need to investigate further." See: racism.

Korryn Gaines was killed in Baltimore, Md. even though she was holding her son. To this day, people still blame her for her own death despite police being trained in de-escalation. They didn't care for her (or her son's life). Because: Black woman.

Remember Jordan Davis? He was killed because Michael Dunn, an older whiteWhite man, didn't like how loud his music was. He killed him and went back home to eat pizza. This was also in Florida. That older man said he was he was intimatted and that Davis had a gun.

Point is: young blackBlack people are not given the chance to be victims or survivors; only perpetrators of violence. This is played out (and defended) in the media who only exacerbate this dangerous narrative. It must stop.
So, yes, @CNN, @MSNBC, @democracynow, @FoxNews (not that we expect much for you, in particular), it is incumbent to offer perspectives that will uplift the most marginalized.
Not that y'all will all care... but just a thought from a Black person.
